title: Likelihood function
summary: The likelihood function (often simply called the likelihood) describes the joint probability of the observed data as a function of the parameters of the chosen statistical model.[1] For each specific parameter value θ {\displaystyle \theta } in the parameter space, the likelihood function p ( y | θ ) {\displaystyle p(y|\theta )} therefore assigns a probabilistic prediction to the observed data y {\displaystyle y} . Since it is essentially the product of sampling densities, the likelihood generally encapsulates both the data-generating process as well as the missing-data mechanism that produced the observed sample.
